title: Braden Score for Pressure Ulcers
description: Identifies patients at risk for pressure ulcers by assessing six key factors: sensory perception, moisture, activity, mobility, nutrition, and friction/shear

parameters.name: sensory_perception
parameters.description: Ability to respond meaningfully to pressure-related discomfort

labels.1: Completely limited: unresponsive to painful stimuli due to diminished level of consciousness or sedation, or limited ability to feel pain over most of body
labels.2: Very limited: responds only to painful stimuli, cannot communicate discomfort except by moaning or restlessness, or has sensory impairment limiting ability to feel pain over half of body
labels.3: Slightly limited: responds to verbal commands but cannot always communicate discomfort or need to be turned, or has some sensory impairment limiting ability to feel pain in 1-2 extremities
labels.4: No impairment: responds to verbal commands, has no sensory deficit which would limit ability to feel or voice pain or discomfort

parameters.name: moisture
parameters.description: Degree to which skin is exposed to moisture

labels.1: Constantly moist: skin is kept moist almost constantly by perspiration, urine, etc. Dampness is detected every time patient is moved or turned
labels.2: Very moist: skin is often but not always moist. Linen must be changed at least once a shift
labels.3: Occasionally moist: skin is occasionally moist, requiring an extra linen change approximately once a day
labels.4: Rarely moist: skin is usually dry, linen only requires changing at routine intervals

labels.2: Chairfast: ability to walk severely limited or non-existent. Cannot bear own weight and/or must be assisted into chair or wheelchair
labels.3: Walks occasionally: walks occasionally during day but for very short distances, with or without assistance. Spends majority of each shift in bed or chair
labels.4: Walks frequently: walks outside the room at least twice a day and inside room at least once every 2 hours during waking hours

parameters.name: mobility
parameters.description: Ability to change and control body position

labels.1: Completely immobile: does not make even slight changes in body or extremity position without assistance
labels.2: Very limited: makes occasional slight changes in body or extremity position but unable to make frequent or significant changes independently
labels.3: Slightly limited: makes frequent though slight changes in body or extremity position independently
labels.4: No limitation: makes major and frequent changes in position without assistance

labels.1: Very poor: never eats a complete meal. Rarely eats more than 1/3 of any food offered. Eats 2 servings or less of protein per day. Takes fluids poorly. Does not take a liquid dietary supplement
labels.2: Probably inadequate: rarely eats a complete meal and generally eats only about 1/2 of any food offered. Protein intake includes only 3 servings of meat or dairy products per day. Occasionally will take a dietary supplement
labels.3: Adequate: eats over half of most meals. Eats a total of 4 servings of protein each day. Occasionally will refuse a meal, but will usually take a supplement when offered
labels.4: Excellent: eats most of every meal. Never refuses a meal. Usually eats a total of 4 or more servings of meat and dairy products. Occasionally eats between meals. Does not require supplementation

parameters.name: friction_shear
parameters.description: Friction and shear forces when moving

labels.1: Problem: requires moderate to maximum assistance in moving. Complete lifting without sliding against sheets is impossible. Frequently slides down in bed or chair, requiring frequent repositioning with maximum assistance
labels.2: Potential problem: moves feebly or requires minimum assistance. During a move, skin probably slides to some extent against sheets, chair, restraints, or other devices
labels.3: No apparent problem: moves in bed and in chair independently and has sufficient muscle strength to lift up completely during move

result.name: braden_score
result.description: Total Braden score ranging from 6-23 points

ranges.interpretation: Patient is not at risk for developing pressure ulcers. Continue routine skin care and monitoring. Reassess if patient condition changes.
Patient is at mild risk for developing pressure ulcers. Implement basic preventive measures including turning schedule every 2-3 hours, skin moisturization, and nutritional support.

Patient is at moderate risk for developing pressure ulcers. Implement turning schedule every 2 hours, use pressure-reducing surfaces, optimize nutrition and hydration, and perform daily comprehensive skin assessments.

Patient is at high risk for developing pressure ulcers. Implement aggressive prevention protocol: turning every 1-2 hours, specialized support surfaces, nutritional consultation, moisture management, and twice-daily skin assessments.

ranges.description: Very high risk for pressure ulcers
ranges.interpretation: Patient is at very high risk for developing pressure ulcers. Implement maximum prevention measures: hourly repositioning, advanced pressure redistribution surfaces, intensive nutritional support, barrier creams, and frequent comprehensive skin assessments. Consider wound care specialist consultation.

references: Braden BJ, Bergstrom N. Clinical utility of the Braden scale for Predicting Pressure Sore Risk. Decubitus. 1989 Aug;2(3):44-6, 50-1.
Bergstrom N, Braden BJ, Laguzza A, Holman V. The Braden Scale for Predicting Pressure Sore Risk. Nurs Res. 1987 Jul-Aug;36(4):205-10.
Braden BJ, Maklebust J. Preventing pressure ulcers with the Braden scale: an update on this easy-to-use tool that assesses a patient's risk. Am J Nurs. 2005 Jun;105(6):70-2.
formula: Braden Score = Sensory Perception (1-4) + Moisture (1-4) + Activity (1-4) + Mobility (1-4) + Nutrition (1-4) + Friction/Shear (1-3)
notes: Lower scores indicate higher risk for pressure ulcer development
The scale should be used on admission and at regular intervals based on patient acuity
Reassessment should occur with any significant change in patient condition
Prevention strategies should be implemented based on risk level
The Braden Scale is validated for use in multiple care settings including acute care, long-term care, and home care
